titleStmt.title: The Neural Mechanisms of Strategic Decision Making

affiliation.orgName: Core Topics and Current Directions" (Springer Nature

analytic.title: The Neural Mechanisms of Strategic Decision Making

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Strategic behavior arises when two or more organisms interact. Our brains evolved to track others' behavior as part of the environment and build mental models of others' strategies and future actions. In this chapter, we review recent advances in the study of strategic decision making in the human brain at the level of functional brain networks. We discuss general approaches to computational models of strategic behavior and evidence supporting their neural implementation. We then turn to speci@ic issues, including neural representation of the social context, strategic uncertainty, and mechanisms such as belief-based learning, mentalization, and high-order strategic reasoning. We conclude with potential future directions and methodological developments.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Strategic interactions are ubiquitous in animal and human groups. To survive, gain rewards, and maintain social status organisms must learn to track and anticipate each other's actions. In most complex settings, this behavior requires mentalization, or theory of mind -the ability to form second-order beliefs or mental models of others' cognition (Frith & Frith, 2005).

Game theory formalizes strategic behavior, representing any interaction involving two or more agents as a set of players, their actions (strategies), probabilistic beliefs, and outcomes (rewards) (Maschler et al., 2020). Using a simple set of assumptions, gametheoretic models can predict the players' behavior, typically described as an equilibrium, a proQile of strategies where no player has the incentive to deviate from the chosen course of action. Concepts such as the Nash equilibrium provide a useful benchmark for the case when the players behave optimally and rationally, using expected utility and Bayesian updating frameworks.

Empirical data, however, often contradict these predictions (C. Camerer, 2003). Humans tend to deviate from rational predictions and can be affected by various external factors such as interaction dynamics, social context, or game complexity. For instance, individuals tend to learn and update their strategy as they play repeatedly, adapting to their opponent (C. Camerer & Ho, 1999;Erev & Roth, 1998) (Figure 1). On the other hand, individual choices can be affected by internal preferences, for instance, inequality aversion (Cox et al., 2017), when in some situations an individual might prefer receiving a fair split of money rather than taking the whole reward for herself.

Neural data provided general support for a dynamic learning account in strategic choices. Over the last 20 years, fMRI studies identiQied a network often referred to as the "social brain" (Adolphs, 2009) (Figure 2). This network typically includes the right and left temporoparietal junction (TPJ), dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC), precuneus, and right and left temporal poles (as well as the superior temporal sulcus (STS)). Some of these regions (particularly the TPJ) have been linked to theory of mind and show higher activity when a task requires mentalization (Carrington & Bailey, 2009;Coricelli, 2005;Koster-Hale & Saxe, 2013;Saxe, 2006aSaxe, , 2006bSaxe & Kanwisher, 2003;Schaafsma et al., 2015;van Veluw & Chance, 2014).

Various theories offered interpretations of the speciQic functional role of the TPJ (Carter et al., 2012;Carter & Huettel, 2013;FeldmanHall et al., 2013;Morishima et al., 2012;Santiesteban et al., 2012;Tso et al., 2018;Young et al., 2010). Most importantly, TPJ seems to be often involved in strategic behavior (Hampton et al., 2008;Coricelli and Nagel, 2009;Hill et al., 2017;Ogawa and Kameda, 2019), including such examples as blufQing (Carter et al., 2012), trust games (Bhatt et al., 2010), consensus (Suzuki et al., 2015), and false advice (Behrens et al., 2008;Diaconescu et al., 2017).

Early research on theory of mind in the brain often used images and vignettes as task conditions (e.g., the Sally-Anne test (Korkiakangas et al., 2016)). In recent years, decision neuroscience and neuroeconomics (Dennison et al., 2022;Konovalov & Krajbich, 2019) have focused on the model-based accounts of the neural mechanisms of mentalization, using strategic games such as matching pennies or Prisoner's dilemmas as laboratory tasks (C. F. Camerer & Hare, 2014;Jiang et al., 2022;Wang & Kwan, 2023). Using well-speciQied games with monetary rewards and computational models can provide a more mechanistic interpretation of activity in the social brain, linking activity in certain areas to speciQic latent variables underlying the decision process (Charpentier & O'Doherty, 2018;Cutler & Campbell-Meiklejohn, 2019;Konovalov et al., 2018;Olsson et al., 2020;Rusch et al., 2020).

div.head: Computational models of strategic behavior
div.p: The neuroscientiQic method often restricts the set of tasks that can be used for this purpose. While game theory can make predictions even for one-shot interactions, given the noise in the neural signal, many trials are typically required in the laboratory. Strategic tasks used in fMRI or EEG studies thus typically involve repeated games with hundreds of rounds, most often with only two players or artiQicial opponents. Such games often have mixed strategy equilibria, where players are predicted to randomize their actions, which adds an extra level of noise to the data. Given the repeated nature of play, learning models that take into account feedback can be the appropriate way of interpreting these data.

Computational models have a set of assumptions. Players are typically assumed to assign subjective values to the actions they choose in each round (Figure 1). Values determine choices, which are then transformed into rewards by the game task. Players receive feedback (their own and their opponent's rewards, as well as the opponent's choice) and use this feedback to guide their future strategy.

Feedback is hypothesized to affect players' strategic choices in multiple ways. Early behavioral economics studies showed that individuals use reinforcement learning in games by simply repeating rewarded actions (Erev & Roth, 1998;Roth & Erev, 1995). Under some conditions, such behavior can converge to the game-theoretic equilibrium (C. Camerer, 2003). Given the strong evidence for the neural mechanisms supporting reinforcement learning in humans and the use of prediction errors in non-social tasks (Botvinick et al., 2015), it is reasonable to expect these mechanisms to be shared by social and non-social choices (Lockwood et al., 2020). The value of actions is typically found to be encoded by the vmPFC (Bartra et al., 2013), while prediction errors correlate with activity in the striatum (Abler et al., 2006), which is also typically conQirmed for strategic tasks.

However, simple reinforcement is often suboptimal in strategic situations. Another useful strategy is :ictitious play or belief-based learning (Boylan & El-Gamal, 1993) (Figure 1). The player can simply estimate the opponent's historical choice distribution (in other words, form :irst-order beliefs) and try to choose actions that are optimal given this distribution. There is converging neural evidence that such a tracking process might be performed by the regions of the dmPFC or ACC (anterior cingulate cortex) (Hampton et al., 2008;Zhu et al., 2012).

Mentalization allows for more complex strategies. If an agent knows that her actions are being tracked, she can form second-order beliefs and modify her strategy according to her opponent's reaction. One example of such behavior is the level-k, cognitive hierarchy, and k-ToM theories that assume that players have different levels of strategic sophistication (C. F. Camerer et al., 2004;d'Arc et al., 2020;Devaine et al., 2014;Nagel, 1995). An agent at level 0 would simply behave randomly, a level 1 agent optimally responds to that behavior, and a level-2 agent optimally responds to level 1 (in the level-k framework) or to a distribution of level 0 and level 1 (in the cognitive hierarchy framework); this reasoning process can also reach higher levels.

In dyadic dynamic tasks, such behavior can be described using the in:luence learning model: if the agent is aware that her opponent is tracking past history of her own choices, she can adjust the strategy to inQluence the opponent's behavior ( Figure 1) (Hampton et al., 2008). Neural evidence suggests that increased levels of reasoning are linked to higher activity in the regions of the social brain (Coricelli & Nagel, 2009) and that in dynamic interactions, mentalization-driven prediction errors are linked to activity in the TPJ (Hampton et al., 2008). Disruption of activity in this region using transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) can lead to diminished use of high-order beliefs (Hill et al., 2017).

Despite the rapid progress in the Qield, many open questions remain. Neural activations during strategic tasks overlap with the regions of the social brain network (Konovalov et al., 2021), reward network (Zhu et al., 2012), default mode network (DMN) (Duan et al., 2012), and other areas with various functions. It is unclear whether these activations reQlect domain-speciQic computations (related to the algorithmic demands of strategic decision making) or domain-general (related to the mere presence of social context) (Lockwood et al., 2020;Rusch & Charpentier, 2021). It is unclear how these regions exactly perform the related computations and how different these activations are between non-strategic and strategic tasks (Parr et al., 2020). Finally, interactions between individual traits (such as social preferences) and general strategic computations remain to be uncovered.

div.head: Social context and uncertainty
div.p: Two regions of the social brain most often linked to strategic behavior are the dmPFC and TPJ. Given that both areas are not uniquely linked to social behavior (Carter & Huettel, 2013;Eickhoff et al., 2016), their precise computational roles are yet to be determined. One limiting factor is the ubiquitous presence of potential confounds in strategic tasks, including informational complexity, attentional demands, lack of control for social contexts, multiple linked processes (choice, uncertainty, valuation, preferences, and so on), and even varying visual presentations.

In early studies, activations in the social network areas were often linked to the presence of a social context or the task requiring mentalization. One recent study found that if the social context and computational demands are carefully controlled, higher activity in the dmPFC and TPJ is not simply modulated by social framing ("you are playing against a human opponent" versus "you are playing against a computer") but is instead driven by the strategy of the opponent, with more reactive partner eliciting stronger activations (Konovalov et al., 2021).

On the other hand, Reverberi et al. (2022) did not observe signiQicant correlations of strategic complexity in the theory of mind networks but only registered them in the multiple demand network (MDN, which typically involves the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex, insula, and regions of the intraparietal sulcus) and only in subjects with higher cognitive skills. As this network can be modulated by activity in many non-social cognitive tasks, complexity remains an important potential confound for studies of strategic decision making.

Furthermore, there is some converging evidence that basic decision processes (such as value encoding and comparison) are common between social and non-social decisions. Arabadzhiyska et al. (2022) used the combined EEG-MRI approach in a trust game to compare these two contexts and found that the temporal evidence integration process is very similar across the two contexts, reQlected in the medial prefrontal cortex activity. However, the study also identiQied a degree of spatial dissociation, with social context engaging more posterior areas of mPFC and non-social context engaging more anterior areas.

Finally, uncertainty is also a common confound in strategic choices. Playing against an unpredictable opponent can be viewed as a lottery, introducing risk to decisions. Nagel et al. (2018) showed that the risk-processing network, which includes the insula, dmPFC, and parts of the parietal cortex, can also be activated during strategic choices. However, the study also manipulated the level of strategic thinking by changing the type of game the subjects played (a stag hunt game versus an entry game), showing that activity in this network also reQlected the level of strategic complexity.

div.head: Tracking others' behavior
div.p: Converging evidence from several Qields of neuroscience suggests that the dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC) is the key region that encodes and stores social information, including other individuals' identities (Báez-Mendoza et al., 2021;Merritt et al., 2021). Using single neuron recordings in a non-strategic vignette task, Jamali et al. (2021) found that individual neurons can encode information about other people's beliefs and dissociate between the individual's and other's beliefs, predicting whether they are true or false.

These Qindings can potentially be extended to dynamic interactions, proposing that the dmPFC can track and update beliefs about the other's actions. In repeated games, the dmPFC's main functional role has been linked to updating Qirst-order beliefs ("What is my opponent doing?") (Hampton et al., 2008;Hill et al., 2017). Applying inhibitory TMS to dmPFC can potentially impair belief updating after negative prediction errors (Christian et al., 2024). However, simple encoding of action prediction errors could still be only a part of the full mechanism.

For instance, the dmPFC might encode not only the momentary updates in beliefs but also the general opponent tracking strategy or sensitivity to their actions. Konovalov et al. (2021) link the dmPFC activity to a computational model parameter that determines how sensitive the subject was to the actions of the opponent in the preceding trial, across a whole block of trials played against that opponent.

Additionally, as discussed above, the dmPFC is also sensitive to strategic complexity and the number of reasoning steps required to Qind the optimal strategy. In many tasks, higher-order reasoning produces stronger dmPFC activations (Zhen & Yu, 2021), and functional connectivity between the dmPFC and TPJ reQlects the use of higher-order reasoning (Hill et al., 2017;Zhen & Yu, 2021).

div.head: Individual and social value
div.p: Another mechanism crucial for strategic decision making is the dissociation between individual and social value. Many studies supported the existence of some "common currency" encoding in the brain encompassing all types of decisions, involving the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC) and basal ganglia (typically the ventral striatum) (Arabadzhiyska et al., 2022;Bartra et al., 2013;Ruff & Fehr, 2014). However, some recent studies of strategic choices suggest a more complex mechanism of integration between individual and social rewards under various speciQic conditions of the game (group decision making, social hierarchy, or cooperative goals).

For instance, using a group decision-making task (a public goods game), Park et al. (2019) found a spatial dissociation between individual rewards and group utility. While the vmPFC encodes expected rewards for the individual, group utility is encoded in the lateral frontopolar cortex. These regions also change their connectivity with the ACC during strategy switching.

Additionally, the value-related activity in the PFC can reQlect the social hierarchy. Using a non-strategic preference rating task, Kim et al. (2023) identiQied a spatial dissociation in the PFC indicating the social rank. The activity in the ventral mPFC increased with more alignment between the preferences of the individual and a superior partner, while the rostral mPFC activity was modulated by goal-based conformity.

Finally, strategic decisions can involve both competitive and cooperative motives. Philippe et al. (2024) used artiQicial opponents that, unknowingly to the subjects, alternated between competitive and cooperative strategies in a matching pennies game. Subjects adapted to these changes and were able to arbitrate between competitive and cooperative learning strategies. The neural data showed that the vmPFC and striatum tracked the reliability of these strategies, reQlecting learning above and beyond simple reinforcement.

Data from a lesion study suggests that the striatum might not even be necessary for successful strategic learning (Zhu et al., 2019). While patients with damage to the orbitofrontal cortex show worse learning in a strategic game, patients with lesions to the basal ganglia learn as well as the control group and can anticipate the opponents' behavior. However, both groups are impaired when they are not given information about the strategic context (Zhu et al., 2019).

div.head: Mentalization and higher-order reasoning
div.p: The temporoparietal junction (TPJ) is most often linked to attention reorientation and mentalization (Carter & Huettel, 2013;Krall et al., 2015;Saxe & Kanwisher, 2003). In strategic tasks, its activity often correlates with second-order belief updates (Hampton et al., 2008;Hill et al., 2017;Konovalov et al., 2021), but its computational role must be more complex.

Given its location, the TPJ is an easy target for brain stimulation interventions that elucidate some of the potential functions of this area. Disruption of activity in the TPJ tends to decrease reliance on mentalization and decreases the connectivity between the TPJ and dmPFC in the repeated inspection game (Hill et al., 2017). In a donation task involving moral values, disruption of the TPJ leads to a reduced impact of the conQlict between moral and material values (Obeso et al., 2018). In the ultimatum game, inhibitory TMS administered to the TPJ changes the counterfactual evaluation of the offer (Ogawa et al., 2023). In the holdup game, disruption of TPJ activity using tDCS changes the subjects' perception of own and other's beneQits, while activation of the TPJ improves mentalization (Xiaoqin et al., 2023). Finally, activation of the TPJ in the patent race game increases reliance on belief-based learning (H. Zhang et al., 2024). Taken together, these results point to a causal role of the TPJ in strategic decisions, although it might be difQicult to identify the common underlying computation given the diversity of tasks and choice contexts.

Most neural evidence suggests that the TPJ is primarily involved in instantaneous updating mechanisms rather than long-term strategy. Using a modiQied dictator game Park et al. (2021) suggest that the recruitment of the TPJ represents the integration of prediction in the face of conQlicting evidence (e.g., violated expectations of generosity). Functional connectivity of the TPJ can be modulated by changes in feedback or strategy. Konovalov et al. (2021) showed that connectivity between the TPJ and nucleus accumbens reQlected losses against a reactive opponent strategy that requires mentalization. Using a bargaining game, Yang et al. (2022) found an increase in the interaction between the TPJ and the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (dlPFC) when subjects engaged in strategic deception.

Recent evidence also suggests that the TPJ might play a role in adaptive mentalization. Using a dynamic cognitive hierarchy model, Buergi et al. (2024) link activity in the TPJ to the update not just on the opponent's actions but also on the opponent's level of reasoning (an individual who can achieve a high level of reasoning can also identify the level her opponent is playing at).

div.head: Future directions
div.p: There are still many open questions in the study of strategic decision making. Further clariQication of the functional roles of the regions of the social networks and their interactions with the reward networks and the general task networks will most likely remain at the core of research on this topic.

One natural new direction is the use of hyperscanning (recording neural signals from several participants simultaneously), which still remains a relatively rare method in the study of strategic choices given its cost and complexity (Liu et al., 2017;Xie et al., 2020;D. Zhang, 2018). One recent study suggested that neural synchrony between two interacting subjects requires mutual presence in the same space rather than simply predicting the other's choices (Kayhan et al., 2022).

The space of potential strategic tasks is rich and must expand beyond simple competitive zero-sum games that only require belief updating mechanisms. Tasks like trust games and social dilemma games also involve individual motivations such as guilt aversion, inequity aversion, and risk preferences, which can involve interaction with other neural substrates (van Baar et al., 2019). An interesting recent direction is the study of self-other mergence, in terms of estimating own and others' abilities and preferences, with the dmPFC playing an important computational role (Wittmann et al., 2021).

In this chapter, we did not discuss hormones, which can potentially play an important role in strategic interactions, prosociality, and aggression. Recent evidence suggests that administering testosterone to male subjects can decrease strategic prosociality and the need to adapt to social expectations (Kutlikova et al., 2023), although the hormone's neural impact mechanism is yet to be determined.

Finally, MRI and EEG data are not the only window into the hidden mechanisms underlying strategic decisions. Other types of choice process data, such as response times and eye-tracking data, can also provide important insights into strategic decision making (Cooper et al., 2019;Konovalov & Ruff, 2022). For instance, gaze and response times can inform others about a decision-maker's prosociality or hidden preferences and can thus be used strategically (Bavard et al., 2024;Fischbacher et al., 2022;Konovalov & Krajbich, 2023).

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Research on strategic decision making in the brain is an excellent example of an interdisciplinary collaboration between economics, psychology, and neuroscience. Further advancements in this topic will allow us to build better, neurally informed gametheoretic models and improve our understanding of the functional roles of speciQic brain regions. IdentiQied deQiciencies in these functions and underlying computations can be useful in studying neurodiversity in social cognition, including autism and disorders such as psychopathy and apathy.

figure.head: Figure 1 .
figure.figDesc: A general model of dynamic strategic interactions in dyads. The decision maker stores subjective values of actions, which guide their choice. The game structure transforms the choices of the two players (including the past history of choices) into rewards. The other's choices can affect the decision maker's future beliefs through belief-based learning mechanisms. The decision maker's own choice can affect future beliefs through in@luence learning (second-order beliefs). The decision maker's rewards can affect the action values through reinforcement learning. Subjective beliefs determine subjective values of actions through expected utility calculations.

figure.head: Figure 2 .
figure.figDesc: Regions of the social brain network. An automated meta-analysis extracted from Neurosynth.org using the term "social" (1302 studies): the ventromedial prefrontal cortex (vmPFC), dorsomedial prefrontal cortex (dmPFC), amygdala, left and right temporoparietal junctions (lTPJ and rTPJ), precuneus. The yellow color represents BOLD signal activations; the numbers represent axial MNI coordinates.
